segment.tokens: The Arabs have five noble races
which that of Kohlan is the most for its beauty , temper , courage , memory , and almost human intelligence
The value the Arabs themselves set upon their horses
The value may perhaps be exemplified
when I say
that the before-mentioned mare ( Cora ) had been brought to the coast in some secret manner
as soon as it transpired
where she was a comparatively insignificant Sultan of the interior sent to offer goods for her to the value of three hundred pounds
When her master left Africa
he sold her to a general officer
I never heard
what became of her after that
The following is a _ short _ of one of these valuable creatures " In the name of God the merciful
The cause of the present writing is
that we witness

that the grey horse Derrish of Mahomet Bey is of the first breed of Nedgdee horses , whose mother is the grey mare , Hadha the famous , and whose father is the bay horse , Dabrouge , of the horses of the tribe Benihaled
the first breed of Nedgdee horses mother is the grey Hadha the famous
whose father is the bay Dabrouge of the horses of the tribe Benihaled
We testify on our conscience and fortune
that he is the
which the prophet said the true runners strike fire
the true runners when they run
they grant prosperity until the day of judgment
We have testified "
what is known
God knows
who are true
Six signatures verified this pedigree
I had marked out a selection of quotations as proofs of the high qualities of the noble horse
I must now be as as possible
I not profit too much by the interesting labours of others
I therefore continue my own observations
When staying on the borders of the river Gambia I saw two of the native horses which belonged to the stud of the Commandant there
the native horses belonged to the stud of the Commandant there
they had been brought from the interior
they taken from a wild herd
they were totally unlike the races hitherto described
The mare of a reddish brown had been some neither of them possessing sufficient character to be referred to the Barb , the Dongola , or the Nubian breeds
domesticated
The mare of a reddish brown was
The mare of a reddish brown well behaved
They were not handsome his legs well-shaped
the male had not been from his native forests
the male was the best looking
carried his head well
was strongly
compactly made especially about the shoulders
there was much fire about the head , which , however , was far from handsome
the head however was from handsome
his legs were well-shaped
The peculiar circumstances I was placed
The peculiar circumstances rendered
it necessary that I should for the sake of health take horse-exercise
There was nothing
nothing could carry me except this little grey horse
for I could not persuade those around me to let
me mount Cora
because they said
she had so hard a mouth
so a side-saddle was put on
a man with a skirt tried the grey once twice
he was tolerably
without much disturbance he went pretty well for a few weeks the only trouble being to get upon his back
He however had one great peculiarity
one great peculiarity manifested itself rather awkwardly
when a party of us started to go to a distance
He could not endure strangers
He would not suffer any of his own kind to approach him
him did not live in the same stable as himself
This was great in a horse just wild from the woods the instant
so it was
my companions approached me
he made a bolt
his heels went into the air
it was in vain to resist his fancy
We returned the next day not
a creek we had crossed in a canoe
while fording a creek the day before one of our party forgot my horse peculiarity
one of our party came up to me
he darted fairly out to sea not
till he found himself off his legs
he was
he frightened
fortunately alarm made him tractable
I easily turned his head
I landed in safety
Wishing however to punish him
I galloped him home four miles through loose sand , which was over his fetlocks
loose sand was over his fetlocks
being subdued
when I had dismounted
I went to pat his check
far however he tried to bite me
taken as a whole
The beauty excellence of English horses have been acknowledged to surpass those of the rest of the world
their speed their enormous leaps their long journeys their strength have been frequent of admiration
I regret
that I can not fill more pages with the histories that are recorded of them
the histories are recorded of them
but there are many excellent books on that subject alone , which may be read with great advantage
that subject alone may be read with great advantage

I pass on to a very clever hunter , called Nannie , who belonged to my father , and who performed a feat , thought , in my childhood , to be unique , but which I have of late seen mentioned in the papers
called
Nannie belonged to my father
who performed a feat
Nannie thought in my childhood
which I have of late seen
mentioned in the papers
as accomplished by other horses
In those days gentlemen seldom retired from the dinner table
gentlemen on an occasion of this sort , my father , by way of summing up his favourite 's wonderful abilities said "
he was
she would at his bidding jump over the supper table , " which was then set out for about twenty persons
the supper table " was then set out for about twenty persons
I was often allowed to exceed the hours
the hours children are usually sent to bed
I was therefore during the whole scene
Doubts were expressed
bets were laid
the parties became excited
Nannie was ordered from her stable , bridled and saddled for her master 's riding
She was led into the room
the gentlemen were all assembled
the table was glittering with lights , glass , and silver
the room was also
at first Nannie was a little
The chairs were set on each side of the room the docile creature
as the seats were pushed under
but they only added to the height
my father mounted the docile creature
my father said
my father " Over "
Nannie
poised herself on her hind legs
stretched out her neck as if to measure the distance
cleared the whole the only ill effect
arising which
my father was
that the marks of her hoofs were left in the carpet
This clever mare constantly opened the door of her stable
This clever mare went to warm herself at the fire in the harness-room
her affection for her master had more than once preserved his life
On one occasion it is supposed
he had slipped off her
it been to get on again
overcome with sleep
when he folded his arms
rested them against her side laying his head upon them remained there in a sound slumber
It was presumed
they had been in this posture a long
had she moved
his life would probably have been endangered the fall
for they were to a steep declivity
On another occasion she came home
she neighed at the door of the dwelling
she did not offer to go to the stable
the family were aroused
servants rose
she trotted back
she stood by her master , who was lying senseless by the side of the road
her master was lying senseless by the side of the road
They must have fallen together
as on his chest was the of one of her feet , probably made in getting up again
probably made getting up again
He was only stunned in a few days
recovered from his fall
while she was more than ever loved
She was a chestnut with a white star very
like her was which
called Peggy
having belonged especially to our mother
we as children claimed as ours also
I have always when recollecting her been to picture to myself the intimacy between horses and human beings in an Arab family
We crawled over her we clung to her neck
we seated ourselves upon her without bridle or saddle
when she had no room for us on her back
we sat upon her
as she herself lay in her stall
When she was
we administered the medicine
almost quarreling to
who should take the gruel to her
when she heard our voices
whatever pain she was
whatever pain she saluted us with a neigh
she was under every infliction , accommodated herself to every fancy , with her prudence good temper
accommodated herself to every fancy
she was often to our safety
Although she had been a
was a lady
she went well in harness for her steadiness forbearance
she used to run in a curricle with all the fiery spirits whom my father chose to drive
all the fiery spirits my father chose to drive
we must have been dashed to pieces more than once for her steadiness forbearance
At last we were obliged to part with her
is
that we were going to live
where we could not keep her
a friend took her into his park , where she was to remain free all the rest of her life
where she was to remain free all the rest of her life
Five years after I was sitting at an open window in the neighbourhood of the metropolis
a sound met my ear
If ever I heard Peggy step
" I exclaimed
" " that is "
she is now coming along the road
I was disbelieved

in one minute after the still beautiful creature though thirty-three years old was at the gate : we rushed to her ; we called her ; she answered us ; she danced about ; she rubbed her face against ours ; she looked for the same caresses , the same niceties which she used to get from us -- and half an hour quickly passed in mutual caresses
we rushed to her
we called her
she answered us
she danced about
she rubbed her face against ours
she looked for the same caresses , the same niceties which she used to get from us
the same niceties she used to get from us
half an hour quickly passed in mutual caresses
The gentleman park she had been living
The gentleman had found her so fresh
that he had ridden her by easy journeys to London
The gentleman during his few days ' visit sent her to see us
she lived two years after that
she died of old age without a struggle
